item.title: Henri Bergius
item.description:
Henri Bergius

Hacker and an occasional adventurer. Author of Create.js and NoFlo. Decoupling software, one piece at a time.

item.title: You Can't Destroy the Village to Save It: W3C vs DRM, Round Two
item.description:
You Can't Destroy the Village to Save It: W3C vs DRM, Round Two

The World Wide Web Consortium (W3C), the nonprofit body that maintains the Web's core standards, made a terrible mistake in 2013: they decided to add DRM-the digital locks that train your computer to say "I can't let you do that, Dave"; rather than "Yes, boss"-to the Web's standards.

item.title: The first working Hyperloop could arrive by the end of 2016
item.description:
The first working Hyperloop could arrive by the end of 2016

Rob Lloyd, the recently-minted CEO of Hyperloop Technologies, believes that his firm will have a fully-working test loop ready for the end of the year. The executive is here at CES to oversee the breaking ground on the facility which is being constructed on the outskirts of Las Vegas.

item.title: The Big Red Button
item.description:
The Big Red Button

Automation is all around us: elevators, automatic doors at the supermarket, and auto-pilots on airplanes. For the most part, we never think about it. It makes our lives easier, cheaper, and safer. But with every new automation, there is this transitional moment. When something first goes automatic, it is disorienting.

item.title: Google Street View Tours The World's Largest Model Railway 'Miniatur Wunderland'
item.description:
Google Street View Tours The World's Largest Model Railway 'Miniatur Wunderland'

Google Street View has been on many expeditions through time and through our planet, from the Amazon to Greenland, from the Philippines to Jordan to Machu Picchu, but no mission has been as cute as this exploration of the world's largest model railway in Hamburg, Miniatur Wunderland.

item.title: Hackers and Heroes: Rise of the CCC and Hackerspaces
item.description:
Hackers and Heroes: Rise of the CCC and Hackerspaces

From its roots in phone phreaking to the crackdowns and legal precedents that drove hacking mostly underground (or into business), hacker culture in the United States has seen a lot over the last three decades. Perhaps the biggest standout is the L0pht, a visible 1990s US hackerspace that engaged in open disclosure and was, arguably, the last of the publicly influential US hacker groups.

item.title: How This Company Creates Instant Websites
item.description:
How This Company Creates Instant Websites

When photographer Benjamin Edwards wants to update his website, all he has to do is load a new picture onto his phone; drag it into his web host, The Grid; and voilà, the program loads it onto his home-page and rearranges and recolors the entire site to work with the new image. For his work on behalf of charities such as World Relief that takes him around the globe, the technology is a godsend.

item.title: The Deep Space of Digital Reading
item.description:
The Deep Space of Digital Reading

In A History of Reading, the Canadian novelist and essayist Alberto Manguel describes a remarkable transformation of human consciousness, which took place around the 10th century A.D.: the advent of silent reading. Human beings have been reading for thousands of years, but in antiquity, the normal thing was to read aloud.

item.title: NASA's New Office Is Our Defense Against Death From the Skies
item.description:
NASA's New Office Is Our Defense Against Death From the Skies

It'd be such a shame to lose this fragile, watery planet to an asteroid strike. NASA's newly-formalized Planetary Defense Coordination Office will do its best to save us - money and physics permitting.

item.title: People Without Electricity Don't Get 8 Hours' Sleep Either
item.description:
People Without Electricity Don't Get 8 Hours' Sleep Either

Don't blame the lure of a glowing smartphone for keeping you up too late. Even people without modern technology don't sleep the night away, new research says. Members of three hunter-gatherer societies who lack electricity-and thus evenings filled with Facebook, Candy Crush, and 200 TV channels-get an average of only 6.4 hours of shut-eye a night, scientists have found.
